reviewText: Pirate Captain wants to win the Pirate of the Year award.  The problem is, although he is followed by a very loyal, if somewhat misfit crew, he's just not a very good pirate.  The reasons why his crew loves him becomes obvious as his kind heart and general over looking of everyone's faults, including his own, makes him a fun guy to be around.  Until he meets Darwin who informs him his "parrot" is not a parrot.  Envisioning awards of gold that will get him to the top in the pirate competition, Pirate Captain sets his sights on winning the scientist of the year award.  Unfortunatel, the queen envies his "parrot" and soon Pirate Captain is faced with a difficult decision that separates him from his crew and the parrot.  Then he has to redeem himself and save the parrot, while being saved himself.The story line is a wonderful lesson for kids and adults alike with lots of good, clean fun along the way.  There's lots for everyone to laugh at, but it avoids the potty humor so many movies feel like they need to stoop to.The claytronics are superb.I really enjoyed watching this movie with my girls.
Title: N/A

Title: N/A

reviewText: After years of disappointment the Pirate Captain (Hugh Grant) resolves to finally win the Pirate of the Year competition and so embarks on a series of raids on passing ships in the hope of earning sufficient booty to compete with the his rivals Cutlass Liz (Salma Hayek) and Black Belamy (Jeremy Piven). However he is still plagued by bad luck with the best produced by a succession of raids being the capture of Charles Darwin (David Tennant). Still at least Darwin is able to identify that Pirate Captain's beloved parrot Polly is in fact a dodo, supposedly extinct for over a hundred years. This gives them both an idea...!Pirates! is a gloriously hilarious, exquisitely produced movie. Its very much a children's movie but with plenty of sly asides to keep adults on their toes as well. The sets are stupendous and almost beg a second viewing in themselves to allow the viewer to try to aborb all the teeming detail. Both the voice performances of the cast, and the painstaking detail of the stop-motion animation are flawless.I thought it as close to perfect a piece of film-making as I have seen in many years and I hope for more adventures of the Pirate Captain and his crew in the not to distant future.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As with all Aardvark productions, the animation is superb - you would need to watch this film several times to catch every nuance, every gag. But whereas Pirates! is great family viewing, it is somehow less appealing to adults that Chicken Run or Wallace and Grommet. A couple of obvious gags were not fully exploited; having Darwin plagiarize "evolution" from the Pirate Captain was a distinct possibility, or having the Pirate Captain fall in love with the "obvious" female crew member... these are twists which would've registered more with adults and which simply failed to materialize. However it's still a very good film, beautifully made, very clever, funny and full of eye candy. Just don't get your hopes too high - it's basically a kid's movie front and center.

reviewText: Uh, really?Okay, I'll be honest, I'm not part of the big "pirate" trend that happened a few years ago.  Honestly, I don't get it.  Glamorizing a particular type of criminal seemed odd to me when the trend started.That said, I really can't find any merit in this film.  It's very long and boring.  There's not enough plot to keep anyone's attention.  The scenes drag on and never really go anywhere.  There was one funny scene with a bathtub.  The rest are utter non-sense.Not to spoil it for anyone who chooses to waste their own time in this life... This movie is centered around the mushy emotional relationship of a crappy pirate and his crew.  That's why I say, "really?"The captain is not a ferocious and cruel type, and he's not heroic and loyal, and he's not even the ridiculously focused on, emotional and values his relationship type.  He's worthless and this movie is in character with the captain.  Add to that, the characters are not funny, and the lines are not funny either.The adventure type scenes are too ridiculous to be exciting, and end up boring.  The queen's character is too bizarre to be entertaining.  The only value was clearly in the animation and claymation style of film making.  I think the queen's character was created just for the animators pleasure, but surely not the audience's.Wallace and Grommit's, "the Wrong Trousers", is the only film they've produced that I thought was aimed at and entertaining for the whole family.  The rest of their films always leaves me asking, who was this aimed at?  Too boring for adults and older kids, and often scenes too disturbing and frightening for the youngest viewers, but not the type of storyline that would appeal to youngsters anyhow.  Maybe these films are geared for other film makers.This movie is so worthless, I hope you consider spending your family's time watching higher quality cinema.  It's hard to find these days, but it's out there, good luck.
summary: Who was this made for?  Absolutely worthless film

reviewText: I remember sitting in the theater to see The Muppet Movie and seeing this hilarious film trailer and thinking that I absolutely couldn't wait to see it.  I see so many cartoons that it is a joy to find one that truly appeals to both adults and children.  It is also fun to find one that isn't so dark.  The recent trend with the princess movies is sad (Princess and the Frog and Brave both at times being downright scary) and so I'm always looking for a FUN film to watch with my daughters.  Well, we never got around to seeing this in the theaters, but last night we snuggled up on the couch to take it all in, and I'm so happy that we did.This was hilarious!The Pirates! Band of Misfits tells the story of The Pirate Captain, a simple minded man who captains a ship that is, well, not all there.  His ship his falling apart, his crew is week and incompetent, his parrot is fat and in a society where the more feared you are the more important you are seen, The Pirate Captain is only worth 12 doubloons.  Still, The Pirate Captain is hopeful of becoming Pirate of the Year.  He applies and then sets off on an adventure to find a lot of booty.But he hits a snag when he meets Charles Darwin and finds out that his fat parrot is anything but a parrot, but is the long thought extinct Dodo Bird.  What happens next is pure hilarity.The Claymation process is astonishing and so much fun to watch, and the progression of story is great.  It never grows tired because each additional slice of storyline feels intended and fresh.  I couldn't stop laughing, and the visual gags are met each step of the way with smart humor.  The plaque cards are a great touch and the pirate humor is golden.  Nothing feels wasted or unnecessary.  The voice work is superb, with Hugh Grant and David Tennant taking the cake.At the end of the day, these misfits hit it out of the park!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Synopsis: In a pirate haven, just as the pirate captain is putting in his application for the Pirate of the Year award, assured by his crew that he's a shoo-in, three other contenders arrive that put his "achievements" to shame. So he sets out to board more ships in order to gain more gold. No luck. After four failed attempts, he boards a scientific expedition ship, headed by Charles Darwin (yes, that Darwin). Just as Darwin is about to be executed, he notices that the pirate's "parrot" is actually an extinct dodo and he convinces the captain to take it to London and apply for the Scientist of the Year Award, hoping that it will lead to riches. They do so and they stay at Darwin's home, where a trained chimp wearing a tuxedo and using cards with which to write messages does Darwin's bidding. Queen Victoria takes an odd interest in the rare fowl and that's as far as I'll go with the plot.This animated film is by the same folks that brought you Wallace and Grommit. It is very amusing and well done. As is the case nowadays with most animated features, there are jokes and slapstick elements for the kids to enjoy and quite a few jokes for the adults (we get to see cameos by Jane Austen and the elephan man). Some of the sets have jokes of their own which you have to be on the lookout for because they unfortunately are so fleeting.

reviewText: I guess Pixar has spoiled the world for me.  The vast majority of their films are clever, well-written, multi-layerd stories filled with surprising nuances - consider the whole opening sequence of Up, or the underlying themes of the Incredibles or the Toy Story series.  I did enjoy the Walace and Gromit films and Chicken Run, but this film seemed to lack whatever they had in common with their computer animated cousins.  It felt one dimensional and seemed to leer in your face like some of the poorer children's programing does, instead of the perhaps not too subtle wink at the camera the better cartoons have always had - from Bugs Bunny up through the Tick (animated) and beyond.It wasn't terrible ... it had some moments ... but just didn't do it for me in the end.

reviewText: Pirates is a good movie if you're a kid but for adults it can all be a little silly. What follows is mostly screwball type comedy with occasional pop culture references. It's not bad, just not great. My advice is to wait till you can watch it for free.

reviewText: Delightfully loony, Queen Victoria as a despicable villainess with an odd appetite, Charles Darwin as a mercenary out to win a science award by any means necessary, and a Pirate Captain who wants nothing more than to win Pirate of the Year for claiming the greatest bounty of booty imagined.  We soon learn that he and his cutthroat band of misfits are all masters of disguise and that "London (circa 1837) smells like grandma."  I enjoyed their crazy misadventures immensely.  It's funny and fun with loads of sight gags and odd bits of humor.  How can you not love a parrot that's actually a dodo?  That, and ham night.What's the best part of being a pirate?  "The chance to catch exotic diseases."

reviewText: The Pirates! Band of Misfits, or as it is more correctly known The Pirates! In An Adventure with Scientists! but... Americans.This is the latest stop-motion animation from Aardman Animation (best known for their Wallace and Gromit animations) and you can't miss their style in this, both visually and in the script.It doesn't quite hit those heights, lacking perhaps the juxstaposition of the familiar and homely with the fantastical, but it easily offers more originality and wit than 90% of family oriented animated movies.Visually this is the most ambitious stop-animated work I've ever seen. It maintains the claymation look that Aardman are known for, while effectively blending in computer animation for the backgrounds of the sea and sky amongst other things.  It works very well and doesn't detract from the unique Aardman look.The story is not what you'd call deep and covers familiar territory for children's movies but the balance of visual and verbal gags effectively plays to the adults in the audience as well as the kids. With a relatively short running time you certainly aren't let feeling bored at any stage.Another thing worth noting is the stellar (primarily British) voice cast from top to bottom. Even relatively minor characters get the perfect voices. Although unfortunately a couple were replaced in the US version by American actors because.... Americans.So, if you've got kids this is a good one for them to watch because you'll enjoy it yourself. If you like stop motion animation... you need to watch the masters in action. And if you're just looking for a way to pass the time, this will be better than most options.

reviewText: IMHO a certain bare minimum of logic is required by even the silliest of stories; this astonishing embarrassment doesn't even come close.  How could the people responsible forWallace & GromitandFlushed Awayhave produced this disaster?Let's start with the utterly unengaging hero, The Pirate Captain (That's his name not his title).  Utterly incompetent and a good deal less intelligent than the pet Dodo Bird he thinks is a parrot, The Captain (for short) is nevertheless beloved by his crew for no discernible reason other than the fact that he is willing to tolerate their own incompetence.  (They makeThe Pirates of Penzancelook like the undead pirates ofPirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearlin comparison).The Captain's pirating life of beard growing, singing sea shanties, waving shiny cutlasses, futile attempts at gathering loot, and Ham Night is finally exposed to his own eyes as the laughingstock it is to real pirates by the sudden realization that he's never won and never will win the annual Pirate of the Year contest because winning is based on the amount of loot gathered, and he hasn't gathered any.  EVER.  However, the ridicule from other pirates provokes him into entering the contest again anyway, and what follows is the single most ineffective voyage in the history of piracy until he captures Charles Darwin who recognizes that Polly is a thought-to-be-extinct Dodo Bird and assures The Captain that Polly will be sufficient to win the Scientist of the Year contest and "untold riches".  Putting two and two together and coming up with five, The Captain allows himself to be conned into sailing for England, despite Queen Victoria's virulent hatred and prosecution of pirates where only Extremely Stupid Luck (The Captain isn't bright enough to have Dumb Luck.) saves him (and Polly) again and again from the ludicrous yet unfunny (hard to do but the movie makers manage) evil schemes of Charles Darwin and Queen Victoria (?).Though the occasional joke or running gag works, which earned it an extra star from me, this movie is mostly a collection of unfunny bits, mistimed jokes, inappropriate humor for children, forgotten plot elements (The reason one of the pirates is a woman badly disguised as a man?  Apparently none because nothing is ever done with it.), and over-the-top schemes (SPOILER ALERT It turns out that Queen Victoria wants the Dodo so that she and a stereotypical parody group of world leaders, including Napoleon and Uncle Sam, can cook and eat it....  END SPOILER ALERT) that will have you shaking your head in astonishment.  Somebody thought this was funny?  Somebody SOBER thought this was funny?  I'd be inclined to sympathize with Gideon Defoe over the way the screenwriter ruined his bookThe Pirates! In an Adventure with Scientists: A Novel, except that it turns out he WAS the screenwriter so instead I'll be deleting all of his books from my Wish List.  Frankly, the best bit in the entire movie is Bobo the Man-Panzee, a chimpanzee Darwin taught to communicate with note cards.  The gags involving said note cards are invariably hilarious.Not recommended for either children or adults.

He attempts to compete, but the odds are not on his side. He decides to give up the whole idea and heads to England, where he must face more challenges. A fun-filled adventure from beginning to end, and at times hilarious. Animation is good and overall movie is enjoyable. A great summer movie for children!

reviewText: From the "Wallace & Gromit" claymation people comes a very nicely crafted claymation production (the fish in a pirate's hat was great) with excellent detail and creative character making. My only complaint with this side of the production was a plasticity of sameness and lack of depth (soulfulness) in the overall storyline. Storyline was a roller coaster ride of viewer engagement with too much on the ho-hum side of the ride. Not in the same class as Vinton, Burton and the French animation studios. One example, and even the Wallace & Gromit productions have this weakness, is the faces and especially the eyes display a cut-out mode of sameness; almost as if they had a box of mass produced eyes and gave them to all the characters.The dialogue was contemporary and intelligent. The voicing was OK but it would be good if animation studios would spend more time looking for interesting voices rather than just pay for an actor's name to stick in the credits.
summary: Nice Claymation; Good Script; Fair Story

reviewText: "The Pirates! Band of Misfits" is the latest from Aardman Animations, the studio who brought to life "Chicken Run" and the fantastic Wallace and Gromit. In this adventure, Aardman Animations tackles the high seas focusing on The Pirate Captain and his dream of winning the Pirate of the Year award. Who holds the most booty receives the reward. The Pirate Captain and his crew set off attacking ship after ship in search of gold. But when the Pirate Captain meets scientist Charles Darwin, the two have a misunderstanding about unlimited wealth causing the Pirate Captain to choose between riches and re-discovering the true meaning why people become pirates. Based off Gideon Defoe's novels, the adaptation is an 88 minute decent 3/5 stars. If it weren't for a few plot holes and a few boring moments where I wanted the characters to "get on with it!", it might've lived up to it's overhyped trailer. It's not one of those "once you've viewed the trailer, you've seen it all" but it's CLOSE! I don't recommend theatre admission unless your children really, really want to see it. Fans of the studio (particularly who love Wallace and Gromit) will be disappointed.
summary: It is what it is. The trailer sums up the excitement.

reviewText: SINCE THE introduction of Jack Sparrow, we've come to realize the pirate way of life is a riotous mash-up of misadventure. This smart and funny animated claymation/CGI production from directors Peter Lord and Jeff Newitt, who also teamed up on "Chicken Run" (2000) and "Flushed Away" (2006), is a treat for anyone who loves a clever, good natured joke.That seems to be the pirate's biggest problem, their abiding trust and naiveté in an England beset by the Industrial Revolution, Darwinism and a mad Queen Victoria, who is representative of those with very rich appetites. Names are simple. The Pirate Captain, voiced by Hugh Grant - and you will never recognize him - longs to win the Pirate of the Year award, a feat that's defeated him for 20 years. His loyal crew - The Pirate with a Scarf a.k.a. No. 2, (Martin Freeman, "Sherlock," "The Hobbit"), The Albino Pirate (Anton Yelchin), The Surprisingly Curvaceous Pirate (a woman disguised as a man voiced by Ashley Jensen), The Pirate Who Likes Sunsets and Kittens (Al Roker), and The Pirate with Gout (Brendan Gleeson) - do their best to help. But it isn't until they run into the actual theory-of-evolution Darwin, voiced by David Tennant of "Dr. Who," that they discover they might have a chance at winning something ... even if it means the sacrifice of something they love.Bright moments abound. I caught an appearance by The Elephant Man right off, but didn't see Jane Austen until the second go. I'll bet there's more I missed. Could Conan Doyle or Charles Dickens be in a scene somewhere, too?There's good crossover between the Blu-ray, 3D Blu-ray and DVD discs among the extras. A commentary with Lord, Newitt and film editor Justin Krish is loaded with information, but seems dull, particularly compared with onscreen antics. I suspect it's a result of the dry, British wit going Sahara on us. "So You Want to be a Pirate" is a hoot with the Pirate Captain hosting his own late-night TV show, guests included. Games include "Mr. Bobo's Flash Card Challenge" (Darwin's assistant, a monkey and another great character) and a DVD-ROM where kids can download activities and coloring pages on the DVD. There's an interactive game, "Pirate Disquise Dress-Up," on the Blu-ray.Exclusive to Blu-ray is one of the best extras, an engaging making-of "From Stop to Motion"; a featurette on "Creating the Bath (tub) Chase Sequence"; and two short films from Peter Lord.Speaking of the Blu-ray - both picture and sound are reference quality GREAT. Color, depth, detail, contrast - it's all there for the HD connoisseur. The film is dialogue heavy, so most of the sound broadcasts front and center. It is also great; each voice - with accent - comes through clearly and distinctly. Comical effects abound, blending in perfectly. There's nothing to distract from the action. Highly recommended for everyone!

reviewText: This is one of those cases where the trailers for the movie made me not want to see it ever.  I saw the trailers before many other movies and all they showed me was a bunch of slapstick humor scenes edited together which revealed nothing of the plot (or even if the movie had a plot), and I didn't think they humor was very funny.  Now that I've seen those same scenes in context in the movie I realize how funny they are.  And dumbing down the title from "The Pirates! An Adventure with scientists" to "The Pirates! Band of Misfits" was self-defeating, because all pirates are by definition misfits, aren't they?  But "an adventure with scientists" would have told me that this is no ordinary pirate movie.So despite the efforts of the promoters of this movie to made it look like a totally moronic waste of time, I ended up taking my two boys to the theater to see it one day when there was nothing much to do, one of the kids and I are suffering from seasonal allergies, and mom wants us out of the house.  I had a great time and am looking forward to seeing this movie again and catching things that got by me the first time through.
summary: The trailers made me not want to see it, but I'm sure glad I did.

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: MOVIE REVIEW #28: " Pirates: Band of Misfits "Well....I love Aardman films....(creators of Wallace & Grommit)...and directors Peter Lord (who also directed Chicken Run) and Jeff Newitt (key animator on Flushed Away) made a visually stunning clay-mation feature that is filled with panoramic views of old London, the Caribbean and the open sea!The movie's got a talented voice cast and some great gags that are short snippets of slapstick - even some one-liners that are quite funny. However, the movie lacks two very important things; an interesting and not too predictable story and characters we should care more about.Gideon Defoe who wrote the screenplay based on his own book....didn't seem to capture the magic that is a feature film style animation. The movie seemed to play on the `emotions' of the lead character called The Pirate Captain as voiced by Hugh Grant (Noting Hill, Music & Lyrics), but it seems a little shallow in the `believability' part of this character. Hugh did a great job personifying an uptight, unaware and obviously persecuted pirate captain, but without the script it falls a little short.Some other amazing vocal performances came from David Tennant (Fright Night, Doctor Who) who performed the not yet famous Charles Darwin and a generously evil performance by the Queen of England as voiced by Imelda Staunton (Harry Potter: OOTP, Shakespeare In Love). Other funny performances came from Anton Yelchin (Star Trek, Fright Night) as an Albino Pirate and Jeremy Piven (Entourage, The Family Man) as Black Bellamy an ego driven pirate who always wins the Pirate of The Year Award!The sole quest of The Pirate Captain is to prove himself - after 75 attempts - that he can actually win The Pirate of the Year Award.....except he is not very bright, his crew is a literal band of misfits and he happens on a scientist (Darwin) that discovers his very own parrot is actually not a parrot but a Dodo Bird. Something thought to be extinct. Then the story shifts to being about making it on time to a Science fair. Yawn.There are some great bits - but not enough to justify the 90 minutes or film or even the 3-D. The movie would have been just as fine outside the 3-D marketing. The kids in the audience I was in were not as into the film as I thought they might be....so overall a nice family film but probably worth waiting for on cable or the DVD.I was disappointed but somewhat entertained.
summary: Pirates - Fell A Little Short For Me

reviewText: Pirates have become cool again with the trilogy of films made by Johnny Depp but those films might be just a tad too intense for the youngest of children. With that in mind the folks at Aardman studios, the stop motion group responsible for Wallace and Gromitt among other things, have come up with some pirates of their own. They've just been unleashed with this film.The story follows a group of pirates that aren't quite up to snuff in the pirate hierarchy. Sure they have the peg legs and eye patches, but this ragtag group just doesn't seem to pillage near as much as most. They're led by the Pirate Captain who does his best to keep his crew happy and content (hey, don't forget ham night!). But Pirate Captain has dreams of his own, of becoming the Pirate of the Year.The only problem is the amount of pirating he and his crew does. With Cutlass Liz and Black Bellamy always bringing in more booty they win the competition every year. Rather than allow him the chance to do better, the group always ridicules him as well.That could all change when Captain Pirate and his crew board a boat stocked with all sorts of stuffed animals and body parts. The boat belongs to Charles Darwin who's been seeking a special scientific discovery so that he can become the Scientist of the Year award back in London. He too has had a tuff time but when he sees Captain Pirate's parrot he recognizes it is not a parrot at all but the extinct dodo bird. Darwin convinces Captain Pirate to take him to London along with the bird where they will win all sorts of treasures for their discovery.Even though the queen has placed a bounty on the heads of every pirate to sail the seven seas the group heads for London. Once there Darwin attempts to steal the bird from Captain Pirate to claim the award for himself. He fails and Captain Pirate wins the award, stunned to find that it isn't booty at all but an award along with the chance for time with, of all people, the Queen! Darwin failed to mention the reward would be time spent with the woman of his dreams.The Queen also wants possession of the dodo bird for her private zoo but Captain Pirate doesn't give in easily. After discovering he is a pirate and nearly decapitating him, she stops and pardons him in the hopes he will turn over the bird. When she offers treasure as well, Captain Pirate sees the chance to return to Blood Island with more booty than anyone has ever claimed and win the prized Pirate of the Year award. But all doesn't go as planned, something that always seems the case with this group.The story may seem pretty well straight forward but in truth there is more beneath the obvious here. It's not just about Captain Pirate winning the award and gaining some self esteem. Instead the story is more about discovering who you really are and what is really important in life. For Captain Pirate that boils down to winning the award he's cherished for so long or remaining true to both Polly (the dodo bird) and his crew.As with all Aardman Studio films this one is chock full of sight gags that run from beginning to end. Each one may be a small portion of the film seen but they all will garner laughs from adults as well as children. They do a nice combination of jokes that older viewers will get but won't offend the young crowd.The stop motion animation is as always amazing. In a world where computer animation seems to have taken over, it's nice to see someone using this technique and not allowing it to fade away. Somehow just watching it makes you realize how creative and artistic it is in comparison.The final word about this film though is that it is truly entertaining. It's a movie that both young and old will enjoy and have fun with. Topping that off is the fact that it offers something that youngsters will not realize they are getting and that is a set of morals to accompany the tale. They'll learn that wanting something and doing anything for it at the sake of losing everything that is truly important isn't quite worth it. And for a movie to entertain and get that point across is truly an amazing feat. So hoist the rigging and set sale for the high seas with this film that the whole family can enjoy.

reviewText: Strangely high number of very positive reviews here.  The movie was visually stunning, (computer animation enhanced claymation)  but poor in story and humor. Charles Darwin and Queen Victoria are the over the top dastardly villains in this, which should give you a good impression of the pervasive wrongness present here. A few chuckles now and again, but nothing to appreciate more on a second viewing. I'm not a kid, so I can't speak with full authority on their potential enjoyment, but I would guess it would be low. All I know is that Wallace and Gromit and Chicken Run are fantastic fun every time, and this was disappointing.  Very odd sort of ironic sensibilities here (probably very British humor) that miss more than they hit and are definitely over the heads of younger kids, and a majority of the older ones as well. (also can't speak for the 3D.)  Rent, don't buy.
summary: I never want to watch it again

reviewText: I remember seeing the advertisement for the movie & thinking that it looked cute.  But rarely do I race out anymore to see a film based on the trailer, having been burned too many times.  I soon forgot about it & just happened to see it at Christmas time on cable.  We landed on it while channel surfing & got sucked in immediately.  When there were mere minutes left, the TV shut off inexplicably.  I was surprised that I wondered about the ending for weeks afterwards.  This odd little film got under my skin.  So two months later I finally ordered it on Amazon.  I watched it as soon as it came out of the packaging & considered jumping to the ending where the TV had shut off, but opted instead to watch it in its entirety.  I was happy to discover that it was just as enjoyable as the first time around.  I recommend The Pirates! Band of Misfits for anyone wishing to escape for 88 minutes into a well animated, cleverly written saga of the endearing Pirate Captain & his band of loveable misfits.  I suspect there will be a sequel; at least I hope so.
summary: The Pirates will steal your heart

reviewText: I wanted to like this movie.  I really did.  I was all set to like it.  I remember the trailer for it, not knowing anything about it, and thinking that it would be fun, funny, and an animated delight.  Well, the animation was a delight at least.But the stop-motion claymation work in the vein of Wallace & Gromit isn't enough to propel this children's pop-up book adventure into equally enjoyable adult territory.  I'm not saying that the kids won't like this (I'm sure that they would and that is what's most important) but when so many animated kids movies these days are also made with an eye toward the adults who will also be in the room this one sinks before it gets out of port.  The jokes, many of them visual, simply fall flat and the story fails to get under sail with anything resembling a strong headwind.  Pity.The story is about Pirate Captain and his crew hoping to win a "Captain of the Year" award and their zany misadventure while doing so.  Pirate Captain is voiced by Hugh Grant.  Unfortunately his foibled, stuttering affect doesn't translate to this character with great humorous effect.If you could get this movie on the cheap or you have already seen it and enjoy it then, heave ho!  If not, I'd advise to put a wary finger up to the wind and to tread carefully on this sea.  There's far better children's (and adult) fare out there than this.
summary: The humor's flat.  The story's flat.  Sailing this sea is...flat.

reviewText: "First off, this film had so much expectations- its brand recognition, animation style, quirky vibes, and British mannerisms. Surprisingly for Aardman, this has to be their weakest but most technically advantageous feature-length film since Flushed Away and The Curse of the Were-Rabbit. I am sorry to say but the film suffers from a stodgy plot, lackluster humour, an unusual fast pace, and lack of development in characterization. What makes it stand out is their signature animation style and accompanying 3D effects. Get a DVD and watch The Wrong Trousers, A Close Shave, and Chicken Run instead. Even Arthur Christmas, one of their CG works, fared better than this one in terms of story."PRO: Strong aimation style and details. 3D effects. Choice of music. Occasional satirical/historical points (esp. Jane Austen, Queen Victoria). 3D effects.CON: Structure and execution of story, themes, plot devices, and humour is flat. Pacing is typically uneven. Deceiving title and name for the British version/title ("In an Adventure with Scientists."). Iffy marketing campaign. Action and thrill feels middling and same.
summary: It's visually rich but the story and results are weak. Disappointing turn for Aardman (a first)!

reviewText: As a big fan of Aardman Animations, I had high hopes for The Pirates! Band of Misfits.  Unfortunately, this film is more a bundle of misfires than anything else.  It's one of those films where, if you've seen the trailer, then you've already seen ninety percent of what's worth seeing in the film.Directed by Peter Lord and Jeff Newitt and written by Gideon Defoe, there's something missing from this film.  What's missing is Nick Park, who was writer and/or director on all of Aardman's best films, from the Wallace & Gromit and Creature Comforts short films to their feature films like The Curse of the Were-Rabbit and Chicken Run.  Park was also the missing element from Aardman's notably less successful films like Flushed Away and Arthur Christmas.  All of the humor and heart and cohesive consistency that Nick Park brings to his projects is absent here.  And boy does it show.The nominal plot centers around The Pirate Captain (that's his name, not his title) and his crew of misfits who sail the seas in an apparently nameless (one of many, many oversights in this film) ship in 1837 when Queen Victoria ruled the British Empire.  Ignoring for the moment the fact that the golden age of piracy actually ended a hundred and fifty years before this film is set, The Pirate Captain (Hugh Grant) is on a quest to win the coveted Pirate of the Year award, which goes to the pirate who accumulates the most plunder. His arch rivals in this endeavor are fellow pirate lords Black Bellamy (Jeremy Piven) and Cutlass Liz (Salma Hayek).  After a truly miserable run of pirating - boarding a leper ship, a ghost ship, and a ship of nudists among others, none of which have anything to plunder - The Pirate Captain ends up boarding the HMS Beagle where he encounters none other than Charles Darwin (David Tennant).  Darwin recognizes the pirates' parrot Polly as not being a parrot at all but instead a dodo, a bird that, thought by all to be long extinct, would be the zoological find of the century.  This turn of events takes the pirates to London where they run afoul of Queen Victoria (Imelda Staunton), ruler of the British empire with a sworn hatred of all things pirate.  Not to mention a taste for, shall we say, quite rare cuisine.The animation - mostly stop-action claymation with some CGI added in - is up to the usual high Aardman Animations standards.  But it's what's going on within the film and the characters that falls woefully short.  The best way I can describe Band of Misfits is that it's like listening to a stand-up comic whose timing is awful, who doesn't know his audience, and who now and then ends up forgetting the punch-line entirely.  I mean, you listen, and you know the jokes are _supposed_ to be funny, but the way they're delivered they're just... not. And also lacking is heart.  There's no real emotional depth or even substance to most of the characters, leaving them largely one-note jokes that wander aimlessly from scene to scene.  As an example of an undelivered punch-line, one of the crew - The Surprisingly Curvaceous Pirate - is obviously a woman pretending to be a man by wearing a fake beard.  But that's all there is.  Lord and Defoe never go anywhere with it; she's never revealed as a woman, she's never in a situation where her being a woman matters in any way, they just have her there as part of the crew, a one-note joke lacking a punch-line for the entire film.  Also wasted was Salma Hayek's Cutlass Liz who definitely catches one's interest - and eye - when she makes her sexy-and-dangerous entrance early in the film... only to pretty much disappear for the rest of the movie until the end when the Pirate of the Year winner is announced. The same goes for Jeremy Piven's Black Bellamy - big flashy whale of an entrance, then nothing to do for the rest of the movie.  And as for not knowing the audience, a lot of the jokes are Darwin/evolution jokes that are going to go right over the heads of any kids, who would seem to be the principle market for the film.  They also won't make the adults laugh either because they're executed so badly.As far as the 3D aspect goes, once again, the 3D here - as in so many recent releases - adds absolutely nothing to the film and amounts to a complete waste of money trying to make a mediocre film seem like more than it is.About the only positive thing I can say about Band of Misfits is that it was genuinely funny to not only see Queen Victoria cast as the villain but also to see her spring into flying ninja two-sword combat mode in the climactic battle scene.  It was also good to hear Brian Blessed's inimitable bass bellow as The Pirate King, even if he only had one scene to use it in. But these two things don't make up for the rest of the movie, not by a long shot.  Band of Misfits is definitely a missed fit on Aardman's part.  It's not as bad as Flushed Away was, but it's nowhere as good as any of the Nick Park films were.Recommended only for die-hard Aardman Animations fans and for anyone who's always wanted to see what Queen Victoria as an arch-villainess would be like.
summary: Band of Misfits largely a bundle of misfires
Title: N/A

reviewText: Bored and depressed, I watched this for a second time last night, and enjoyed it even more than the first.It's nice to see a "family" film that's aimed at least as much as adult sensibilities as children's. Though not quite as good as "Rango", it's a genuinely witty film. And the jokes fly by so quickly it can be hard to follow them. So much is going on in the background (and sometimes the foreground!) that you'd better be ready to hit Pause to watch the action and read the signs (eg, a dentist named D K Ying).There's a bit of naughty humor, some of which might go over an /adult's/ head. My favorite is a pirate saying "London smells like my grandmother." If you don't get it, I won't explain it -- but he's not referring to rose water.Strongly recommended.
summary: More fun for adults than kids (or should I say Kidd's?)
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've come to expect good things from Aardman Animations, and this lives up to my high expectations. The story itself is kid-friendly and amusing, but with plenty for the grownups to enjoy. The generally gentle tone avoids aggression and darker themes, so will probably work well for all but the most skittish of kids. Best of all, production values are of the best quality. The stop-animation figure have just the right goofiness, beautifully animated. The sets are spectacular, too - each one is actually constructed and decorated as you see it on screen, and there are dozens. And, in a few places, it seems that modern technology enhances this most classic of animation styles. Clouds, flame, and water effects work well, adding a touch of realism to the whimsical figures and props. Like the Wallace and Gromit tradition before it, Pirates is a hoot!-- wiredweird

reviewText: We (husband, myself, and first grader) went to watch this movie last weekend, and though my husband hated it, my daughter and I thought it was a fun movie. There is nothing ground-breaking in terms of animation, effects, or plot here - it is what it is - a fun movie that will probably be enjoyed better by kids than by adults.The storyline is simple enough (and I can't compare it to its source work as I've not read the book this is based on) - Pirate Captain (Hugh Grant delivering quite a good voice-over) is a pirate that has seen better days and who has never really achieved any pirating glory. He has however amassed a loyal following in his rag tag crew members, and a pet bird that turns out to be quite, quite unique.Pirate Captain decides he absolutely must enter the Pirate of the Year contest though he is up against some renowned pirates, i.e. sexy female pirate Cutlass Liz (Salma Hayek delivering her lines in a swoon-worthy performance) and several other prominent pirates, all of whom have garnered many glories in their pirating adventures. Feeling out of his depth, Pirate Captain decides to give it up but fate of course has other plans.Pirate Captain and his crew, together with naturalist Charles Darwin (David Tennant) find themselves heading to England, where the pirate-hating Queen Victoria dwells. Will Pirate Captain get what he wants, or will he be doomed like other unfortunate pirates who've felt Victoria's wrath?The story moves along at a mercifully quick pace, and the laughs are there, though nothing stellar. My daughter enjoyed the movie and I thought it was good fun too - though of the forgettable variety. The animation in the tradition of Walllace and Gromit is cool and that was the highlight of the movie for me really. Final verdict - great fun for kids.
Title: N/A
